Award.AwardTitle: NSF-BSF: Universality Puzzles and Coherent Control of Efimov Physics with 7Li Atoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interactions among a few atoms will be explored by this project, and in particular, ways to achieve quantum control in the regime of ultracold temperatures where a gas becomes quantum mechanical in nature. Few-atom systems with their extremely nonperturbative interactions pose some of the greatest challenges for atomic theorists and provide many opportunities to advance our scientific knowledge with potential technological and fundamental impacts. This project represents a theoretical and experimental collaboration via the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF). The goal of the project is to develop the theoretical tools, which, combined with experimental analysis, will enable a detailed investigation of properties of strongly interacting quantum gases with a focal point on developing control of the complex multichannel collision dynamics using either a static external field or an electromagnetic field.

A specific goal is to explore 7Li ultracold quantum gases to understand puzzling observations related to the nature of the universality of Efimov states in the system. These studies will serve as the base of the main focus of this theory-experiment collaboration, which involves the exploration of new physics near the 7Li ultra-narrow Feshbach resonance and atom-dimer mixtures. Particular attention will be given on the determination of the scattering properties and lifetime of Efimov states as well as the underlying physical mechanisms which make 7Li gases a unique system to explore universal quantum physics. The project also includes studies for the implementation of coherent control over few-body processes which can enable the stabilization of strongly interacting gases, by turning off few-body losses, as well as open up ways to control three-body interactions and superposition states, allowing for the creation of exotic dynamical regimes. Beyond that, a deeper understanding of the ultracold atom interactions can spawn applications to atomic clocks, quantum information science, and the exploration of many novel phases of matter. The key educational impact of this work derives from the training of graduate and undergraduate students in state-of-the-art theoretical and computational research techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project goal was to elucidate universal properties of few-body systems as well as to develop ways to coherently control interactions in ultracold quantum gases. Here, the importance of few-body phenomena has both fundamental and practical aspects for a variety of quantum phenomena accessible in quantum gases. In fact these efforts are also relevant to other physics subfields, including atomic and molecular, condensed matter, and nuclear physics. In ultracold quantum gases few-body processes can lead to atomic and molecular losses, dictating their lifetime and stability. Therefore, being able to understand the nature of such processes can enable ways to control them. More recently, however, a increasing number of experiments in ultracold gases have been devoted to the exploration of more fundamental few-body effects and have provided a plenitude of observations of a peculiar quantum phenomenon called the Efimov effect. Predicted nearly 40 years ago, the Efimov effect was first experimentally demonstrated in ultracold quantum gases, and this effect serves now as a quantum workhorse to study some of the deepest aspects of universal few-body physics. Our improved understanding can also spawn a new level of control over chemical reactions, over the ability to uncover novel quantum phases, and over new ways to produce stable gases in exotic dynamical regimes. Few-body systems pose some of the greatest challenges facing theorists in atomic physics because of their extremely nonperturbative nature. 

 

We have developed a better understanding of a number of key aspects of few-body systems that are deeply quantal and which occur in ultracold quantum gases through a theoretical and experimental collaboration stablished by the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF) program. The theory was carried out in the US part of this collaboration while the experimental component by the Israel counterpart (Khaykovich). The present proposal includes a theoretical analysis of various previous experiments with 7Li ultracold quantum gases, to understand puzzling observations related to the nature of the universality of Efimov states in the system. These studies, based on the hyperspherical representation, served as the base of the our newly obtained understanding of the intricated aspects of Efimov physics with 7Li atoms and corresponding coherence properties of our experimental scheme. 

 

The development of new numerical tools has also allowed us to investigate important dynamical aspects of ultracold chemical reactions. In particular, we have determined novel propensity roles for the product state distributions of ultracold three-body recombination with alkali atoms. These advances will pave the path for developing further control of chemical processes which can potentially impact the field of ultracold quantum gases, where such processes can limit their lifetimes and stabilities. 

 

Lastly, during the period of support covered by this grant several publications have been published and results have been broadly disseminated in the community via participation at conferences. Our work has helped to expand our knowledge of universal few-body physics in problems relevant for ultracold quantum gases and has suggested new ways in which few-body physics can be explored experimentally and used to probe novel dynamical regimes.
